p: Epidemics dominated by A(H3N2) were associated with a larger size (4855 (95% CI 4044; 5665) vs 3298 (95% CI 2313; 4283) cases per 100 000 population, P value = 0.01) and higher peak (900 (95% CI 742;1057) vs 631 cases per 100 000 population (95% CI 410; 851), P value = 0.04) compared to all others epidemics. Conversely, epidemics dominated or co‐dominated by virus B were smaller (3010 (95% CI 2197; 3822) vs 4632 (95% CI 3801; 5462) cases per 100 000 population, P value = 0.005) and had a lower peak incidence rate (504 (95% CI 419; 598) vs 896 cases per 100 000 population (95% CI 725; 1067), P value = 2.10 −3) (Figure 3).
